text: (52) Concerns remain, however, because the [Privacy Act 1988] provides no express authority for this proposition and no assurance is provided for the use or disclosure of ‘information that does not show unlawful activity but which is nevertheless necessary for the proper resolution of a dispute’

If the [Privacy Act 1988] presents significant barriers to the information exchange necessary for effective and efficient dispute resolution, then consideration should be given to appropriate amendment

Question 40–2 Should the [Privacy Act 1988] or other relevant legislation be amended to provide exemptions or exceptions applicable to the operation of alternative dispute resolution (ADR) schemes? Specifically, should the proposed:(a) ‘Specific Notification’ principle exempt or except ADR bodies from the requirement to inform an individual about the fact of collection of personal information, including unsolicited personal information, where to do so would prejudice an obligation of privacy owed to a party
55 After the release of IP 31, the [Privacy Act 1988] was amended to insert a new [Privacy Act 1988] , which commenced operation on 7 December 2006

58 Before the Privacy Legislation Amendment (Emergencies and Disasters) Act 2006 (Cth) was passed, a number of stakeholders expressed concern to the ALRC in relation to how the [Privacy Act 1988] operates in emergency situations

As outlined in Chapter 22, the ALRC proposes a number of amendments to the privacy principles to cover threats to health and life and other situations—these may be referred to colloquially as emergencies, but they are not declared emergencies within the meaning of [Privacy Act 1988] of the Act

60 Part VIA arose partly as a response to the concern that the provisions of the [Privacy Act 1988] impeded the ability of agencies and organisations in responding to the emergencies of the terrorist attacks in the United States on 11 September 2001, the Bali bombings of 2002 and the Boxing Day tsunami of 2004
(68) The [Privacy Act 1988] regime responds to this problem by not requiring an entity to establish a particular level of threat before collecting, using or disclosing personal information
62 The application of [Privacy Act 1988] is triggered by a ministerial declaration of an ‘emergency’
A question arises as to whether this is the most appropriate trigger for the [Privacy Act 1988] regime and, if so, whether any refinements need to be made to the triggering process

63 As explained above, where there is a declared emergency, [Privacy Act 1988] provides a separate regime for the collection, use and disclosure of personal information that has the requisite connection to the emergency in question

(70) The combined effect of [Privacy Act 1988] and [Privacy Act 1988] under the [Privacy Act 1988] regime, however, would allow DFAT and other government and non-government entities to make such a disclosure

(71) This is now dealt with in [Privacy Act 1988] and [Privacy Act 1988] , which provide clarity as to how long the [Privacy Act 1988] regime for the collection, use and disclosure of personal information will operate after a declared emergency
69 The ALRC has received few comments on whether [Privacy Act 1988] constitutes an adequate and appropriate regime for handling personal information in the context of emergencies
In view of this consideration, the ALRC does not intend to make [Privacy Act 1988] a particular focus of further consultation

The OPC is an independent statutory body established by the [Privacy Act 1988] (Cth), consisting of the Privacy Commissioner and staff appointed under the Act
The OPC is responsible for administering the [Privacy Act 1988] , and is the federal regulator for privacy in Australia
2 General privacy regulation has operated at a federal level only since the [Privacy Act 1988] was passed in 1988
4 The [Privacy Act 1988] divides the Privacy Commissioner’s functions between interferences with privacy generally, tax file numbers and credit reporting
This division is a product of the historical development of the [Privacy Act 1988]

Consistently with the ALRC’s proposal that the [Privacy Act 1988] should be amended to achieve greater logical consistency, simplicity and clarity,(1) the ALRC considers that it would add greater clarity to the Act to consolidate the functions of the Commissioner where appropriate
7 As the regulator responsible for administering the [Privacy Act 1988] , the primary responsibility of the OPC is to foster and enforce compliance with the [Privacy Act 1988]

In the Issues Paper, Review of Privacy (IP 31), the ALRC discussed the compliance model underpinning the [Privacy Act 1988] —the specific modes for fostering and enforcing compliance, including the statutory provisions and the manner of their administration and enforcement

8 Chapter 42 develops this discussion further by putting forward a model of compliance-oriented regulation as an appropriate framework in which to administer a principles-based regime such as the [Privacy Act 1988]

(5) The chapter applies the construct of compliance-oriented regulation to the [Privacy Act 1988] , considering both the regulatory tools provided in the Act and the strategies and approaches adopted by the OPC in using those tools
The chapter sets out the benefits of adopting an explicit enforcement pyramid approach to enforcing compliance with the [Privacy Act 1988]
The chapter provides an overview of the Privacy Commissioner’s powers and examines the accountability mechanisms which the Commissioner is subject to under the [Privacy Act 1988]
The ALRC also proposes that the matters the Commissioner must have regard to in exercising his or her powers should be aligned with the proposed objects of the [Privacy Act 1988]
11 Chapter 44 examines the functions and powers vested in the Privacy Commissioner by the [Privacy Act 1988]

The general approach of the [Privacy Act 1988] is to state the Commissioner’s ‘functions’ and give the Commissioner ‘power’ to do all things necessary or convenient to be done for or in connection with the performance of his or her functions

While much of this Discussion Paper refers to the ‘OPC’, the actual functions and powers outlined in the [Privacy Act 1988] are vested in the Privacy Commissioner and are to be exercised—or delegated—by the individual appointed as Privacy Commissioner

13 Chapter 44 considers the Privacy Commissioner’s functions of overseeing and monitoring compliance with the [Privacy Act 1988] —including the functions of giving advice and guidance, undertaking educational programs, and conducting audits—and the Commissioner’s powers to issue public interest determinations
The ALRC makes a number of proposals to reform these functions, to expand and strengthen the Commissioner’s powers of securing and monitoring compliance with the [Privacy Act 1988]
14 The ALRC considers the co-regulatory aspects of the [Privacy Act 1988] in Chapter 44
These are the provisions in [Privacy Act 1988] that allow organisations to develop privacy codes, which, when approved by the OPC, replace the NPPs

The ALRC proposes that the [Privacy Act 1988] be amended to empower the Privacy Commissioner to direct an agency or organisation to provide to the Commissioner a privacy impact assessment in relation to a new project or development that the Commissioner considers may have a significant impact on the handling of personal information
16 Concern has been expressed by stakeholders about the current complaint-handling process in the [Privacy Act 1988]

19 The ALRC also proposes that the Privacy Commissioner’s power to remedy systemic issues be enhanced by empowering the Commissioner to prescribe, in a determination, the steps an agency or organisation must take to comply with the [Privacy Act 1988]
20 The second central issue examined in Chapter 45 is the manner in which complaints are resolved under the [Privacy Act 1988]

The ALRC proposes that the [Privacy Act 1988] be amended to provide merits review of all determinations made by the Privacy Commissioner and that the OPC publish a document setting out its complaint-handling policies and procedures
22 Chapter 46 examines the OPC’s powers to enforce compliance with the [Privacy Act 1988]
This own motion investigation power complements the Commissioner’s power under the [Privacy Act 1988] to investigate complaints

This proposal is intended to strengthen the overall enforcement pyramid underpinning the [Privacy Act 1988] , and should provide strong incentives for increased compliance by agencies and organisations
(3) Those functions are [Privacy Act 1988] (Cth) [Privacy Act 1988] , (f), and (m) respectively

1 In the Issues Paper, Review of Privacy (IP 31), the ALRC asked whether the current compliance model used in the [Privacy Act 1988] (Cth) is appropriate and effective to achieve the Act’s purposes, and if not, whether that is because of its content, its administration, or some other reason

It aims to provide a theoretical framework that will help in considering the ALRC’s proposals to expand the functions and powers of the privacy regulator in Australia to facilitate compliance with the [Privacy Act 1988]
3 The [Privacy Act 1988] adopts a principles-based approach to regulating privacy
6 The ALRC considers that compliance-oriented regulation can provide the framework for a principles-based regime such as the [Privacy Act 1988]

The theory on which compliance-oriented regulation is based provides a prism through which to view and assess the compliance model underpinning the [Privacy Act 1988] and the approach taken by the Office of the Privacy Commissioner (OPC) to fostering compliance
It also provides an holistic approach for considering which regulatory strategies would best achieve the objectives of the [Privacy Act 1988]

The chapter considers the elements of compliance-oriented regulation identified by Parker and applies them to the privacy context, focusing on the regulatory tools provided in the [Privacy Act 1988] and the strategies and approaches adopted by the regulator in using those tools

9 This first step of compliance-oriented regulation is reflected in the OPC approach to promoting compliance with the [Privacy Act 1988] , which is based on the premise that ‘compliance will be achieved most often by helping organisations to comply rather than seeking out and punishing the few organisations that do not’
(16) The OPC should have regard to this tension in administering the principles-based regime of the [Privacy Act 1988]

(18) The OPC should continue to encourage the growth of this privacy profession—including through networks such as the privacy contact officer network—to help build compliance into organisational practice and develop a shared understanding of the objectives of the [Privacy Act 1988]
13 The [Privacy Act 1988] already provides the Privacy Commissioner with a number of ways to monitor compliance with certain provisions of the Act by agencies and organisations

To extend the Commissioner’s power to determine whether regulatory objectives are being achieved in organisations as well as agencies, the ALRC proposes that the [Privacy Act 1988] be amended to give the Commissioner a ‘spot audit’ power over organisations
16 There is a level of escalation involved in the approach taken to resolving privacy complaints and taking other enforcement action under the [Privacy Act 1988]
The next level up is for the Privacy Commissioner to make determinations under [Privacy Act 1988] , which can involve an element of sanction via a public declaration of breach
19 Nevertheless, the OPC Review acknowledged the concern expressed by some consumers and privacy advocates that the enforcement of the [Privacy Act 1988] is ‘soft’
20 Several stakeholders commented on the enforcement approach adopted in the [Privacy Act 1988] and by the OPC
Some stakeholders supported the OPC’s current approach to compliance and the compliance model in the [Privacy Act 1988]
(33) Stakeholders also expressed support for the use of Braithwaite’s ‘enforcement pyramid’ as a model for enforcing the [Privacy Act 1988]

22 The ALRC makes several proposals in Chapters 45 and 46 that are aimed at strengthening the restorative elements of complaint-handling under the Act and enhancing the enforcement pyramid adopted in the [Privacy Act 1988] , by expanding the remedies and sanctions available to the Privacy Commissioner when he or she finds an interference with privacy

The ALRC also proposes that the content of the enforcement pyramid adopted in the [Privacy Act 1988] be strengthened with the addition of civil penalties for serious or repeated contraventions of the Act
23 These proposals are consistent with Parker’s model and aim to widen the range of strategies that are available to the OPC to enforce compliance with the [Privacy Act 1988]

25 Consistent with the compliance-oriented regulatory design underpinning the [Privacy Act 1988] , the OPC should implement a compliance policy that adopts an explicit enforcement pyramid approach to restoring compliance and enforcing the [Privacy Act 1988]

The OPC should use, and should be seen to be using, a wide range of strategies to ensure compliance with the [Privacy Act 1988] , recognising the benefits of specific and general deterrence that can be generated by a transparent, balanced and vigorous enforcement approach

The ALRC also makes the proposal to align the matters that the Commissioner must have regard to in performing functions and exercising powers with the proposed objects of the [Privacy Act 1988] (Cth)
3 The role and position of Privacy Commissioner was originally established in the [Privacy Act 1988] , as passed in 1988

4 The Privacy Amendment (Office of the Privacy Commissioner) Act 2000 (Cth) amended the [Privacy Act 1988] to establish the ‘Office of the Privacy Commissioner’, defined to consist of the Privacy Commissioner and staff appointed under [Privacy Act 1988] (2) The [Privacy Act 1988] provides that the Commissioner is appointed by the Governor-General for a period of up to seven years,(3) on such terms and conditions as imposed by the Governor-General and the Act

5 The [Privacy Act 1988] does not provide for a Deputy or Assistant Commissioner (as a statutory appointee), but does provide for the appointment of an Acting Commissioner during any vacancy in the office or absence of the Privacy Commissioner
6 Part IV, Division 2 of the [Privacy Act 1988] vests a range of functions in the Commissioner
7 The [Privacy Act 1988] invests the Commissioner with power to do all things that are necessary or convenient to be done for or in connection with the performance of his or her functions

(9) The Commissioner also has an ancillary function in [Privacy Act 1988] to do anything incidental or conducive to the performance of any of the Commissioner’s other functions in [Privacy Act 1988] (10) Delegation 43

The first is that the [Privacy Act 1988] invests functions in the Privacy Commissioner personally, rather than in the OPC generally, and only the Commissioner has the power to do all things necessary or convenient to be done in connection with the performance of his or her functions

The Commissioner cannot delegate the powers conferred by [Privacy Act 1988] , which sets out the Commissioner’s power to make determinations, and the Commissioner cannot delegate his or her power under [Privacy Act 1988] to issue guidelines relating to tax file number information

15 In terms of the name of the regulator, the OPC reiterated the recommendation made in its review of the private sector provisions of the [Privacy Act 1988] (OPC Review) that its name should be changed to the ‘Australian Privacy Commission’

16 The OPC also commented on the delegation power in its submission, recommending that the exception in the Commissioner’s powers to delegate with regard to [Privacy Act 1988] determinations be amended to allow senior staff of the OPC to undertake determinations

The OPC suggested that this could be done by either introducing a qualified delegation power in respect of the Commissioner’s determination powers or by amending the [Privacy Act 1988] to specify an additional position or positions that would be permitted to exercise the determinations power
To this end, the [Privacy Act 1988] should be amended to allow for the appointment of one or more Deputy Privacy Commissioners

The Deputy Commissioners would be appointed by the Governor-General under the [Privacy Act 1988] for a set period and would enjoy the same level of independence, including through the protections against termination of appointment that currently apply to the Privacy Commissioner
The ALRC’s view is that the determination power is significant and should only be exercised by statutory officers appointed under [Privacy Act 1988]

The proposal to appoint more statutory officers who are expressly authorised to exercise all the powers of the Privacy Commissioner—including a power under [Privacy Act 1988] —respects the significance of the power in [Privacy Act 1988] and ameliorates the problem of it being limited to one person’s availability
Proposal 43–1 The [Privacy Act 1988] should be amended to change the name of the ‘Office of the Privacy Commissioner’ to the ‘Australian Privacy Commission’
Proposal 43–2 [Privacy Act 1988] , Division 1 of the [Privacy Act 1988] should be amended to provide for the appointment by the Governor-General of one or more Deputy Privacy Commissioners

22 In exercising his or her powers under the [Privacy Act 1988] , the Commissioner is bound to have regard to the matters set out in [Privacy Act 1988] The matters in [Privacy Act 1988] can be divided into two principal concerns

First, the [Privacy Act 1988] requires the Commissioner to take the following into account when performing functions and exercising a power: protection of important human rights and social interests that compete with privacy, including the general desirability of a free flow of information (through the media and otherwise) and the recognition of the right of government and business to achieve their objectives in an efficient way;(34) and international obligations accepted by Australia, including those conce

23 Secondly, the [Privacy Act 1988] requires the Commissioner to ensure that his or her recommendations, directions and guidelines are capable of being accepted, adapted and extended throughout Australia,(36) and are consistent with whichever is relevant out of the Information Privacy Principles (IPPs), the National Privacy Principles (NPPs), Credit Reporting Code of Conduct and Part IIIA of the Act

25 The New Zealand [Privacy Act 1988] requires its Privacy Commissioner to have regard to largely the same matters as set out in [Privacy Act 1988] (40) In other jurisdictions, an alternative approach is taken

These functions include powers to oversee the [Privacy Act 1988] (Cth) and to monitor compliance with the Act
2 The Commissioner’s functions in overseeing the operation of the [Privacy Act 1988] include: giving advice; providing research and monitoring of technological developments; and conducting education
3 The Commissioner has several advisory functions under the [Privacy Act 1988]
These are to: Provide advice to a minister, agency or organisation on any matter relevant to the operation of the [Privacy Act 1988]
(7) Provide advice to tax file number (TFN) recipients about their obligations under the Taxation Administration Act 1953 (Cth) and on any matter relevant to the operation of the [Privacy Act 1988]
(8) Provide advice to the adjudicator appointed under a privacy code on any matter relevant to the operation of the [Privacy Act 1988] or the relevant privacy code

5 Another aspect of the Commissioner’s functions in overseeing the [Privacy Act 1988] is undertaking research into, and monitoring developments in, data processing and computer technology (including data-matching and data linkage) to minimise their adverse effects on the privacy of individuals and to report to the Minister about the results of such research and monitoring

Following on from recommendations made in my 2005 review of the private sector provisions of the [Privacy Act 1988] , my Office will work closely with business and consumer representatives to develop guidance and educational material to assist organisations and individuals to better understand their rights and responsibilities under the [Privacy Act 1988]
11 The ALRC asked in the Issues Paper, Review of Privacy (IP 31) whether the Commissioner’s powers to oversee the [Privacy Act 1988] were appropriate and effectively exercised

The ALRC received many stories of ‘BOTPA’ (‘because of the [Privacy Act 1988] ’) explanations being given as a reason for refusing a request for information or assistance from an agency or organisation

The NHMRC submitted that education about the [Privacy Act 1988] for all stakeholders should address, in a balanced manner, individual privacy rights, the public benefit to be obtained from the controlled handling of personal information in the absence of consent in appropriate circumstances, the potential tensions between these objectives in some situations and the ways in which such tensions can be resolved in the overall public interest
The OPC suggested that the importance of education in dealing with developing technologies should be recognised expressly in [Privacy Act 1988] or (m), or both
The wording of [Privacy Act 1988] should be broadened to allow for research and monitoring of any pertinent technologies
This is also consistent with the ALRC’s proposal that the [Privacy Act 1988] be technologically neutral
It is preferable, therefore, that advices (or a generic form of them) are made public if they are relevant to a broader audience and would increase understanding of the [Privacy Act 1988]

As currently worded, the functions provide broad powers for the OPC to educate agencies, organisations and individuals on the content and objects of the privacy principles, the importance of protecting individual privacy, and the rights and obligations provided in the [Privacy Act 1988]

(44) Guidance can be provided through the Commissioner’s oversight functions discussed above, and through the power to issue non-binding and binding guidelines under the [Privacy Act 1988] and other legislation
(45) [Privacy Act 1988] guidelines are advisory only and are not legally binding
Guidelines are based on the OPC’s understanding of how the [Privacy Act 1988] works and indicate some factors the Commissioner may take into account when handling a complaint
(48) Thus, while guidelines issued under [Privacy Act 1988] are not determinative, they are often highly persuasive
28 In addition to the Commissioner’s powers to issue non-binding guidelines, the Commissioner can also issue ‘binding’ statutory guidelines under the [Privacy Act 1988] and other Acts
For example, under [Privacy Act 1988] of the [Privacy Act 1988] , the Commissioner must issue guidelines concerning the collection, storage, use and security of TFN information
(52) These guidelines are made binding by virtue of [Privacy Act 1988] , which prohibits a file number recipient from doing an act or engaging in a practice that breaches the guidelines

(55) File number recipients can also be audited to ascertain whether records of TFN information maintained by the recipient are in accordance with the [Privacy Act 1988] guidelines,(56) which are discussed below

30 The [Privacy Act 1988] also invests the Commissioner with the power to approve guidelines issued by the NHMRC in relation to medical research and genetic information under [Privacy Act 1988] , [Privacy Act 1988] and [Privacy Act 1988]
32 The power to issue guidance is an important part of regulating a principles-based regime such as the [Privacy Act 1988]
Proposal 44–2 The [Privacy Act 1988] should be amended to reflect that where guidelines issued by the Privacy Commissioner are binding they should be renamed ‘rules’

For example, the following should be renamed to reflect that a breach of the rules is an interference with privacy under [Privacy Act 1988] of the [Privacy Act 1988] : (a) Tax File Number Guidelines issued under [Privacy Act 1988] of the [Privacy Act 1988] should be renamed Tax File Number Rules; (b) Medicare and Pharmaceutical Benefits Programs Privacy Guidelines (issued under s 135AA of the National Health Act 1953 (Cth)) should be renamed the Medicare and Pharmaceutical Benefits Programs Privacy Rules; (
The websites in most cases contain much more information than was contemplated when the [Privacy Act 1988] was implemented

Proposal 44–3 Following the adoption of Proposal 21–1 to require agencies to produce and publish Privacy Policies, the [Privacy Act 1988] should be amended to remove the requirement in [Privacy Act 1988] to maintain and publish the Personal Information Digest
43 Privacy impact assessments (PIAs) have been the topic of much discussion in recent reviews of the [Privacy Act 1988] and in privacy commentary more generally
The term ‘privacy impact assessment’ is not defined in the [Privacy Act 1988] , nor is there a requirement for the Commissioner, or for an agency or organisation, to undertake a PIA
(82) Similarly, there are no requirements in the [Privacy Act 1988] for an agency to undertake a PIA

51 The Senate Committee privacy inquiry went further and recommended that the [Privacy Act 1988] ‘be amended to include a statutory (PIA) process to be conducted in relation to new projects or developments which may have a significant impact on the collection, use or matching of personal information’

Given that the agency or organisation’s compliance with the [Privacy Act 1988] is the responsibility of that agency or organisation, the Office considers that the conduct of any PIA should be the responsibility of the particular agency or organisation
68 The OPC suggested that some kind of accountability mechanism should be included in the [Privacy Act 1988] if a statutory requirement for PIAs to be conducted is introduced

PIAs also help to build privacy compliance into the culture and practices of agencies and organisations, which is consistent with the OPC’s overall approach to facilitating compliance with the [Privacy Act 1988]
70 Having regard to those benefits, the ALRC is of the view that PIAs should be given some legislative underpinning in the [Privacy Act 1988]

This could be done by either: amending the [Privacy Act 1988] to include a requirement to prepare a PIA for proposed projects and developments that significantly impact on the handling of personal information; or encouraging the preparation of PIAs and empowering the Commissioner to direct the preparation of a PIA where the Commissioner thinks a project or development is likely to have a significant impact on the handling of personal information
If necessary, the Commissioner could seek an injunction from the Federal Court to stop a project from being implemented if he or she believed it breached the [Privacy Act 1988]

(137) Proposal 44–4 The [Privacy Act 1988] should be amended to empower the Privacy Commissioner to: (a) direct an agency or organisation to provide to the Privacy Commissioner a privacy impact assessment in relation to a new project or development that the Privacy Commissioner considers may have a significant impact on the handling of personal information; and (b) report to the Minister an agency or organisation’s failure to comply with such a direction
